text.__SUMMARY__: The Angolan adder (Bitis heraldica) is a venomous viper species found only in Angola, easily distinguished from B. caudalis by its heavily speckled belly and lack of any supraocular "horns". No subspecies are currently recognized.
text.Taxonomy: The common name is Angolan adder
text.Description: The maximum recorded total length (body + tail) is 405 mm (15.9 in).
text.Distribution and habitat: It is found on the high plateau of central Angola.The type locality given is "sur les bords de la rivière Calae, l'un des affluents de Cunene, entre le 13o et 14o parallèle á l'est de Caconda." [Calai River (tributary of the Kunene), Cacanda, Angola.It commonly inhabits rocky mountain slopes.
text.Behavior: Nothing is known of its behavior, as less than 20 specimens have ever been collected.
text.Venom: Nothing is known of the venom composition, and no bites have ever been recorded.

text.Further reading: Bocage JVB du. 1889. Mélanges erpétologiques. II. Sur une Vipère apparemment nouvelle d'Angola. Jornal de Sciencias Mathematicas, Physicas e Naturaes, Academia Real das Sciencias de Lisboa, Segunda Série 1: 127-128. (Vipera heraldica, nov. sp.)
